seg.seg: (he thinks): Since the master, the Buddha, in his previous existances, has been observing the ten Karmapathas by means of avoiding to transgress each Karmapatha one after the other,
this body, these 32 marks, are the fruit. Why? The keeping away from killing has been given to the master, the Buddha, due to 5 causes.
The pureness of the abstention from infringing the Karmapatha: cause one. The pureness of the abstention from bad practice: (second cause)
the state of not being struck by the thoughts of the wrong views: third cause. At all times [being] in possession of an orientation [towards the good] in one's thought: fourth cause.

In the same was that the keeping away from killing of beings was given to the Buddha due to the five causes, just so [the keeping away] from taking the possessions from others, from [enjoying] pleasure with [the lovers of?] others,
the keeping away from [idle] talk, from greed, from malice, from the wrong path will also be given by the five causes (...)
the teacher Buddha, characterized by pure discipline. In the N. tune: Just like one compassionate has observed the pure observance with the 50 causes
in the same way may I observe with a clear mind the pure observance. In the same way that this one as the fruit of the pure observance has achieved the marks, just so may I obtain [these] 32
(great marks). The king Siṃha, [having seen] on the body of the teacher, the Buddha, the falling of the gods, the desire of the human beings, [the ignorance] of the animals,
the shame and the slaughtering of the infernal beings, and [having considered] also the efforts of the Bodhisattvas on behalf of the entire world
in the hells, in the special hells, among the animals, among the ghosts, on the four continents, in the divine abodes of the six-fold Kāmadhātu
a compassion beyond belief for the beings born in the 50 former places arises in him, he says to himself (...)

p.note: This fragment contains part of the twenty-sixth act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka. An Uy. parallel would be MaitrHami 26, Blatt Ca21-verso (= Blatt 12 of the Hami MS); see 204m, and 32, 35, 64-67.
The fragment partly overlaps with, and immediately follows, (line a1 here = b6 = MaitrHami 26, Bl. C, 21ff.). The following commentary is adapted from 224-228 and 231-235.
The fifth cause is not attested in this text.
